#Text=Cliff
#Text=Jenkins ( incumbent )
#Text=60-year-old Cliff Jenkins is the incumbent for Ward 25 , Don Valley West .
#Text=Previous to that , Jenkins was a client executive for IBM Canada , leading a team of information technology professionals to meet the business needs of a large client .
#Text=Q :
#Text=Describe the three most important issues in your campaign .
#Text=A :
#Text=Managing Toronto 's density explosion :
#Text=The population of Toronto is increasing at about 15,000 people per year .

#Text=New residents require additional infrastructure – increased sewer capacity , more TTC buses , increased solid waste capacity , extension of our subway service to York University and beyond , increased policing capability .
#Text=Just about every municipal service has to be ramped up to meet the increased demands - and ramping up generates significant complexity and increases costs .
#Text=The best estimate of the amount new capital infrastructure required by each new person is $ 20,000 .
#Text=Unfortunately , we receive only about $ 4,000 per person in development charges .
#Text=As a result , we 've had about a $ 240,000,000 capital shortfall every year – which we 've " solved " by increasing debt and seeking handouts from other orders of government .
#Text=This is unsustainable and unacceptable .
#Text=Increasing development charges is the first step towards solving the infrastructure shortfall .
#Text=Protection and preservation of neighbourhoods :
#Text=The density explosion puts great pressure on our stable residential neighbourhoods .
#Text=The City 's Official Plan directs growth to specific places in the City – particularly those serviced by rapid transit .

#Text=But the development industry continues to seek growth in those areas of the City which are NOT targeted for intensification , as well as over-intensification in those areas identified for growth .
#Text=This has immediate negative impacts on neighbouring single-family homes .

#Text=While we have made gains in improving policies of the Official Plan to protect these neighbourhoods , it will be the job of the next Council to ensure that Planning Staff interpret and enforce these policies to really protect them .
#Text=Election Finance Reform :
#Text=While Council has indicated its intent to reform how candidates raise money for election campaigns , it does remain a serious problem that must be fixed .
#Text=VoteToronto , an independent organization , has documented the problems at www . votetoronto . ca of the influence that can result from election contributions of special interest groups .
#Text=The new City Council must finish the job of election finance reform .
#Text=Q :
#Text=What one election issue do you feel is most relevant to your ward in this election ?
#Text=A :
#Text=In Ward 25 , the key issue is protection of neighbourhoods .
#Text=For most people , their investment in their homes is their single biggest investment .
#Text=Intrusive nearby development can have major negative effects .
#Text=For example , at 1000 Mt .

#Text=Pleasant Road , an application for a 13-storey apartment building which would tower over and impact neighbouring single-family homes was deemed , by City planners , to be contrary to the City 's Official Plan and should be refused .
#Text=City Council did refuse the application .
#Text=But , on appeal , the Ontario Municipal Board ( OMB ) overturned the City 's decision .
#Text=City Council must re-enforce policies and processes which protect our stable residential neighbourhoods and must demand OMB reform from the provincial government .
